description: From Afrikaans trek, from Dutch trekken, from Middle Dutch trekken (weak verb) and trēken (“to trek, place, bring, move”, strong verb), from Old Dutch *trekkan, *trekan, from Proto-West Germanic *trekan, from Proto-Germanic *trekaną, *trakjaną (“to drag, haul, scrape, pull”), from Proto-Indo-European *dreg- (“to drag, scrape”).

entries.meaning: (South Africa) A journey by ox wagon.

examples: We're planning a trek up Kilimanjaro.
I would drive to the shops from here; you can walk, but it's quite a trek.

verbs.description: trek (third-person singular simple present treks, present participle trekking, simple past and past participle trekked)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To make a slow or arduous journey.
examples: Before that they had been a good deal on the move, trekking about after the white man, who was one of those rolling stones that keep going round after a soft job.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To journey on foot, especially to hike through mountainous areas.
(South Africa) To travel by ox wagon.
